docs.lead_paragraph: Gary A. Franks is the great-grandson of a slave who picked plantation tobacco and the grandson of a North Carolina tobacco sharecropper. His father grew tobacco on the same plot that his cousins still farm today. He has ''an affinity'' for the tobacco business, he says. And the tobacco business, it seems, has one for him.

headline.main: Tobacco's Contributions Reach Friend and Foe Alike

docs.abstract: Study commissioned by New York Times examines campaign contributions from tobacco industry to New York metropolitan area Congressmen since 1991; study, by Campaign Study Group, finds that Gary A Franks, Republican who was voted out of Congress in 1996 and is now running for United States Senate in Connecticut, has received $64,200 in campaign contributions from tobacco industry since 1991, more than any other current or former congressman from New York met area; Sen Christopher J Dodd, Democrat whom Franks is trying to unseat, has little in common with his challenger, and has often voted against tobacco interests; but in last seven years, he has received $55,699 in donations from tobacco industry; industry has rained contributions on almost every incumbent in Congress, dispensing special largess to proven allies, while still giving generously to occasional adversaries; tables show political candidates in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, and how much they have received from tobacco industry (L)
docs.snippet: Gary A. Franks is the great-grandson of a slave who picked plantation tobacco and the grandson of a North Carolina tobacco sharecropper. His father grew tobacco on the same plot that his cousins still farm today. He has ''an affinity'' for the...

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the nicest things about his job, Joseph F. Corsetto says, is that he goes to a different office every day. It could be in a monumental mansion or a humble ranch, but for three hours someone's house becomes his office, the place where he exercises his expertise. Mr. Corsetto, a home inspector, looks over the houses from top to bottom, walking on roofs, hunkering in tight storage spaces, shimmying into creepy basement crawl spaces, all to provide peace of mind for the home buyers who hire him.
docs.abstract: Article describes work of home inspector Joseph F Corsetto of Lake Parsippany, NJ; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the sprawling plains of Uruguay, where sheep and cattle far outnumber people, the milkman still makes home deliveries by horse and buggy. Elementary school children wear dour uniforms of the same style their grandparents wore. People still turn to radio more than television for the news, and a national hobby is collecting classic jalopies. So perhaps it is not surprising that the winds of economic change sweeping across almost every corner of Latin America fade to a gentle breeze once they cross the Plata River into Uruguay.

headline.main: The Welfare State Is Alive, if Besieged, in Uruguay

docs.abstract: Economic change sweeping Latin America has largely bypassed Uruguay, where welfare state faces biggest test in years, union-sponsored plebiscite opposing new law to let private companies compete with Government's electric monopoly; unions seek to make Pres Julio Maria Sanguinetti, centrist who pushed law through Congress, into lame duck and propel socialist to presidency next year; map; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vera Peragine is waiting anxiously for Bar Beach to open, so she and her friends can go every Monday to listen to the bands and dance. ''Dancing days are over for me,'' said Mildred Edelstein, who now enjoys ice cream socials, where ''I still like to watch others dance and listen to the piano player.''

headline.main: Living to Be 100: Anger, Arthritis and Occasional Joy

docs.abstract: Article on some of estimated 408 residents of Long Island, NY, who are 100 or more years old; nursing homes are expanding services to make their lives as independent as possible; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE 42-year-old from Suffolk County had a strong family history of breast cancer. Her mother, a sister and two aunts had died of the disease. When she learned that she could be genetically tested to find out whether she had the BRCA-1 gene, which predisposes carriers to breast cancer, the woman, who insisted on anonymity, went to University Hospital at Stony Brook.

headline.main: Genetic Tests Gaining for Adult-Onset Ills

docs.abstract: Article on recent advances in predictive gene testing which are allowing people to learn if they are at greater risk of getting certain diseases; focuses on work at five Long Island hospitals (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FROM high up on the Chrysler Building, a man surveys New York City. In an eye-catching 1991 photograph by Annie Leibovitz, this man, the choreographer-dancer David Parsons, is almost naked, stretched out belly down on a gleaming gargoyle, the sunset turning him rosy. Whatever Ms. Leibovitz's agenda was, her picture says a lot about Mr. Parsons. He's an athlete, an achiever, a hunk. His career has prospered. He's a risk taker. Right now, at 39, he's taking a risk that involves neither dancing in midair (as he appears to do in the strobe-flash magic of his signature solo, ''Caught'') nor going out on a choreographic limb (''Pass the Oil, Please,'' a piece that presents two masseurs working on two inert dancers). This risk is financial.

headline.main: Onward and Upward, Gambling on Success

docs.abstract: Deborah Jowitt profiles dancer-choreographer David Parsons and his popular Parsons Dance Company, which is presenting three-week season at City Center; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Graced with a large surplus and a strong economy, Gov. John G. Rowland and Democratic legislative leaders have reached a mostly painless budget agreement in which both sides accomplished what they most wanted. In a compromise made late Thursday, Mr. Rowland, a Republican, secured agreement on the centerpiece of his state budget plan, a proposal that Democrats had at first scoffed at: rebate checks of up to $150 for taxpayers, sent out before the November gubernatorial election.

headline.main: Leaders in Hartford Agree to Budget Deal With Rebates

docs.abstract: Conn Gov John Rowland and Democratic legislative leaders reach mostly painless budget agreement, with help of strong economy and large surplus; Rowland wins rebate checks of up to $150 for taxpayers, to be mailed out before November election; Democrats get to increase property-tax relief and expand rebates to lower-income people (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The profit of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. fell 3.8 percent in the first quarter as profit growth at its financial services units was offset by the strength of the pound. Net income fell to $:333 million ($557 million) from $:346 million a year earlier. The company, the world's second-biggest cigarette maker after Philip Morris, sold fewer cigarettes in the United States because of health concerns and in Asia because of an economic slowdown. Its financial services arm, which will be spun off this year, had strong profit growth in life insurance and general insurance.

headline.main: B.A.T. Industries' Profit Fell in First Quarter

docs.abstract: BAT Industries reports first-quarter net income fell to 333 million pounds ($557 million) from year-earlier $346 million pounds (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Great-West Life and Annuity Insurance Company agreed yesterday to acquire the Anthem Health and Life Insurance Company of Piscataway, N.J. The purchase price will be based on the adjusted book value of Anthem upon closing, currently estimated at $100 million. In a statement, Great-West said the deal would provide it with an additional $975 million of equivalent premium income. Anthem Health, a subsidiary of Anthem Inc., provides life, medical, disability and dental products to small and medium-sized businesses. Great-West Life, based in Denver, provides group life, health and financial products. It is an indirect subsidiary of Great-West Lifeco Inc. of Canada, a member of the Power Financial Corporation.

headline.main: GREAT-WEST LIFE AGREES TO ACQUIRE ANTHEM HEALTH
